history.content: CS 188 is the gateway into much of AI research, and it covers a broad survey of topics in the field. Many professors who work in AI (ex. Sergey Levine, Pieter Abbeel, Anca Dragan, Stuart Russell, Dan Klein, etc.) look for good grades in CS 188 as a prerequisite to joining their labs. If you want to do Machine learning in particular (which is a subfield of AI), then CS 189 is probably more focused and useful.

CS 188 is the gateway into much of AI research, and it covers a broad survey of topics in the field. Many professors who work in AI (ex. Sergey Levine, Pieter Abbeel, Anca Dragan, Stuart Russell, Dan Klein, etc.) look for good grades in CS 188 as a prerequisite to joining their labs. If you want to do Machine learning in particular (which is a subfield of AI), then CS 189 is a good follow-up.

CS 188 is the gateway into much of AI research, and it covers a broad survey of topics in the field. Many professors who work in AI (ex. Sergey Levine, Pieter Abbeel, Anca Dragan, Stuart Russell, Dan Klein, etc.) look for good grades in CS 188 as a prerequisite to joining their labs. If you want to do Machine learning in particular (which is a subfield of AI), then CS 189 is a good follow-up to CS 188 and will prepare you for even more research opportunities.
<md>What kinds of benefits can taking CS 188 offer from a standpoint of getting into research in machine learning (including opportunities here at Berkeley)?</md>
history.subject: CS 188 from a research standpoint
